text: Hi everyone! I'm a graphics engineer at a game studio. Trying out Julia as an alternative to Python for research.
Welcome. What kind of criteria would make Julia a viable alternative to Python for your work? Do you have any particular applications in mind?

elements.text: Welcome. What kind of criteria would make Julia a viable alternative to Python for your work? Do you have any particular applications in mind?

text: Yeah, I'm mostly looking into using it for interactive exploration and graphing, which Pluto.jl seems great for. So far just the format support seems a bit hard (Would like to load EXRs now, could also see geometry formats being a bit of a pain). Going to be looking into a bit of convolution training, which Python has better library support for, but Flux.jl looks useful, and my hope is it being a bit more minimal will be useful, as any models I build I'll likely have to manually convert to be useful for a game. Pretty interested in using Julia's metaprogramming/AST support to try to generate material/shader code. The big challenge is just the huge library support for Python, especially in VFX, an industry adjacent to games as related to rendering.
